ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed increased familiarity with the works of several major philosophers, especially Lacan and Butler.

I was able to witness a unique approach to teaching, one that looks at Antigone in various contexts, attempting to draw out ethical questions from each. The extent to which this project was successful is a bit unclear, but I appreciate the flexibility in discussion, for it tolerated and encouraged different ways to think about interpretation and argument.
I learned how to write short and extended critiques analyzing the interpretations of the play to stimulate questions for better class discussion, which the professor was helpful in encouraging.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I found some of the seminar discussions to be unsatisfying and unproductive at times, but on the whole the readings were interesting and I gained some valuable insights from the student presentations and the professor's comments.

The course gave a lot of opportunities for work with short essays and a presentation, as well as a culminating project, which all forced us to consider the texts in different lights. The professor was a little slow with grading, which caused anxiety for students who were considering dropping or Credit/D-ing the class by midterms, but became better as the year went on, and the feedback was very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would if they had a particular interest in the subject materialthe intersection of philosophy and literature, Hegel, Lacan, Butler, Heideggerand was hoping to engage with short but extremely challenging texts once a week.
